title: Firefighters’ pension scheme 2015 calculator: final scheme design
withdrawn_explanation:
From April 2016, some members will have accrued a year’s service in the 2015 scheme and the calculator is then unable to allow for the actual amounts of accrued benefit in that scheme. As such, figures produced by the calculator should no longer be used. Members should contact their Fire and Rescue Authority if they require a statement of their benefits in the schemes.

title: Building Safety Act 2022 leaseholder protections: what to do
withdrawn_explanation:
Since this webpage was published, The Building Safety (Leaseholder Protections) (Information etc.) (England) Regulations 2022 and The Building Safety (Leaseholder Protections) (England) Regulations 2022 have come into force.

For updated guidance visit: Building safety leaseholder protections: guidance for leaseholders.

To check whether you’ll have to pay to replace cladding or to fix other safety problems with your building, you can use the Leaseholder Protections Checker.

title: Code for sustainable homes: case studies volume 2
withdrawn_explanation:
Following the technical housing standards review, the government has withdrawn the code for sustainable homes, aside from the management of legacy cases.

Legacy cases are those where residential developments are legally contracted to apply a code policy (eg. affordable housing funded through the national Affordable Housing Programme 2015 to 2018, or earlier programme), or where planning permission has been granted subject to a condition stipulating discharge of a code level, and developers are not appealing the condition or seeking to have it removed or varied. In these instances it is possible to continue to conduct code assessments.

Details of the new approach to the setting of technical housing standards in England were announced on 27 March 2015 and a new set of streamlined national technical standards were published. A planning written ministerial statement was also published which outlined the government’s policy on the application of these technical standards for plan making and decision-taking.

The code for sustainable homes webpage is available for the purposes of administering legacy cases only.

title: Code for sustainable homes: case studies volume 3
withdrawn_explanation:
Following the technical housing standards review, the government has withdrawn the code for sustainable homes, aside from the management of legacy cases.

Legacy cases are those where residential developments are legally contracted to apply a code policy (eg. affordable housing funded through the national Affordable Housing Programme 2015 to 2018, or earlier programme), or where planning permission has been granted subject to a condition stipulating discharge of a code level, and developers are not appealing the condition or seeking to have it removed or varied. In these instances it is possible to continue to conduct code assessments.

Details of the new approach to the setting of technical housing standards in England were announced on 27 March 2015 and a new set of streamlined national technical standards were published. A planning written ministerial statement was also published which outlined the government’s policy on the application of these technical standards for plan making and decision-taking.

The code for sustainable homes webpage is available for the purposes of administering legacy cases only.

title: Construction Products Regulation if there is no Brexit deal
withdrawn_explanation:
The UK is leaving the EU.

After 31 January 2020 there will be a transition period until the end of 2020, while the UK and EU negotiate additional arrangements.

For guidance from the end of the transition period, read: Construction Products Regulation from 1 January 2021

You can continue to use CE marking if you’re placing certain construction products on the UK market during the transition period.

For current information, read: EU construction Products Regulation and CE marking including UK product contact point for construction products
